question: Should the UK leave the European Union?

content.source_1: Retained EU Law (Revocation and Reform) Act 2023 (UK legislation) — Ends the supremacy and general principles of EU law in UK domestic law and streamlines the amendment/repeal of retained EU law, evidencing regained legislative and regulatory autonomy as a benefit of leaving the EU. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2023/28/contents/enacted
content.source_2: Office for Budget Responsibility, Economic and fiscal outlook (Nov 2022) — Assesses that Brexit will leave the UK’s trade intensity around 15% lower than if it had remained in the EU and reduce long-run productivity by about 4%, indicating a significant economic cost of leaving. https://obr.uk/efo/economic-and-fiscal-outlook-november-2022/
content.source_3: LSE Centre for Economic Performance, “Brexit has raised the cost of food in the UK by 6%” (Mar 2023) — Empirical analysis attributes a 6% rise in UK food prices to post-Brexit non-tariff barriers, highlighting consumer cost-of-living impacts linked to leaving. https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2023/03/27/brexit-has-raised-the-cost-of-food-in-the-uk-by-6/
content.source_4: UK Government, The Windsor Framework: A new way forward (2023) — Government explainer acknowledges trade frictions and burdens created by the Northern Ireland Protocol and sets out new “green lane/red lane” arrangements to manage GB–NI goods movements, evidencing the complexity and internal market strains arising from Brexit. https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/the-windsor-framework
content.source_5: Department for Business and Trade, CPTPP: Impact Assessment (2023) — Documents the UK’s accession to the CPTPP as an exercise of independent trade policy, with long-run GDP estimated to rise by around 0.08% and new market-access and rules-of-origin opportunities, supporting the claim that leaving enables distinct trade strategies (albeit with modest aggregate gains). https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cptpp-impact-assessment/cptpp-impact-assessment
content.source_6: Genetic Technology (Precision Breeding) Act 2023 (UK legislation) — Legalises the development and marketing of certain gene-edited crops and animals in England, diverging from stricter EU GMO rules; cited by government as unlocking agri-biotech innovation, illustrating regulatory flexibility gained by leaving. https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2023/12/contents/enacted
